title-group.article-title: Biomass nanoarchitectonics of hierarchically porous activated carbon prepared from palm waste fibers for high-performance supercapacitor

abstract.p: The activated carbon fibers (ACFs) were synthesized from Palm waste fibers using a 15 w/v% KOH solution and activated at two temperatures: 500 °C and 800 °C under vacuum conditions. Structural analysis using Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed the formation of carbon structures with integrated K⁺ ions (ACK). Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) revealed that carbon fibers activated at 800 °C exhibit a hierarchically porous morphology. For these activated carbon fibers, the pore size increased to approximately 134 nm, and the total pore volume reached 0.981 cm³/g. Electrical conductivity measurements showed that ACK800 has a high conductivity of 0.64 S/cm, attributed to the enhanced transport of charge carriers across the well-developed porous surface. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve of ACK800 displayed a significant current response and the largest enclosed area among the tested samples, indicating higher capacitance than both CF and ACK500. The specific capacitance of ACK800 was measured at 223.4, 168.5, 138.5, 142.2, and 141.1 F/g at current densities of 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 A/g, respectively. As the current density increased from 1.0 A/g to 10 A/g, the capacitance retention remained high at 97.2%, with minimal capacity loss. Additionally, ACK800 retained 95.68% of its initial discharge capacity. The coulombic efficiency of the ACK800 electrodes was approximately 97.2%, indicating excellent reversibility and stable electrochemical behavior during the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) tests. The well-developed surface morphology of the activated carbon fibers highlights their potential as a sustainable material for environmental remediation and energy storage applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, there has been growing interest in carbon-based supercapacitors due to their potential for high energy storage capacity and rapid charging capabilities. Carbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and activated carbon (AC) are widely used as electrode materials in these devices, owing to their high surface area and excellent electrical conductivity1. Among these, biosynthesized carbon materials are particularly attractive for applications requiring rapid power delivery, as their unique porous structures enable efficient energy storage and fast electron transport2. However, the high production and regeneration costs of commercial activated carbon underscore the need for more affordable precursor materials, particularly those derived from agricultural and forestry waste3. Thus, identifying readily available, cost-effective, and environmentally safe raw materials for AC production is essential4. In addition to carbon content, factors such as raw material availability, transportation requirements, and seasonal quality variations must also be considered in the selection process5,6. Generally, any low-cost material with a high carbon yield and minimal inorganic impurities can serve as an effective precursor for activated carbon production.

For instance, Farma et al.7 demonstrated the preparation of highly porous, binderless activated carbon electrodes from oil palm empty fruit bunch fibers, highlighting their potential for effective energy storage applications. This study reinforces the feasibility of utilizing agricultural byproducts to develop high-performance carbon materials. The electrochemical performance of porous activated carbon in supercapacitors is primarily attributed to its high surface area and optimized pore size distribution. Gu et al.8 emphasized that tailoring the microstructural characteristics of carbon materials can significantly enhance ion transport and adsorption capabilities—factors critical to supercapacitor efficiency. Palm waste fibers offer a promising and sustainable feedstock for producing activated carbon with these desirable features, serving as an environmentally friendly alternative to conventional carbon sources9. In addition to carbon-based materials, conducting polymers and metal oxides have also been widely investigated as electrode materials for supercapacitors10. However, metal oxides often suffer from high costs and low electrical conductivity, while conducting polymers tend to undergo swelling and shrinking during charge–discharge cycles, which compromises their capacity and cycle life5. Despite these limitations, conducting polymers and metal oxides exhibit Faradaic energy storage behavior, characterized by fast and reversible redox reactions, allowing them to achieve high theoretical specific capacitance11.

P. Zhang et al.12 reported on the self-doped (N/O/S) nanoarchitectonics of hierarchically porous carbon derived from palm flowers, highlighting the development of advanced carbon materials optimized for high-performance supercapacitors. These materials exhibit a high surface area and a hierarchical nanoporous structure, both of which are essential for efficient ion diffusion and enhanced electrical conductivity. Such properties are typically achieved through innovative synthesis methods, including the direct carbonization of biomass sources like palm flowers. This process facilitates the incorporation of heteroatoms - such as nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur - into the carbon framework, thereby improving pseudocapacitive behavior and overall electrochemical performance. These advancements contribute to overcoming key challenges in the development of scalable and efficient electrode materials for next-generation energy storage systems, particularly supercapacitors.

Jien Li et al.13 investigated porous Fe₂O₃ nanospheres anchored on activated carbon cloth (Fe₂O₃@ACC), which demonstrated a remarkable area-specific capacitance of up to 2775 mF cm⁻² in a 3 M LiNO₃ electrolyte. Notably, the Material retained 95% of its initial capacitance after 4000 charge-discharge cycles, indicating the presence of rapid, surface-based ion-involved redox reactions. A symmetric supercapacitor assembled using two Fe₂O₃@ACC electrodes achieved an operating voltage of 1.8 V in the same 3 M LiNO₃ aqueous electrolyte, delivering an area-specific capacitance of 1565 mF cm⁻².

At a power density of 12 mW cm⁻³, the symmetric device achieved an energy density of 9.2 mWh cm⁻³. Even at a higher power density of 204 mW cm⁻³, it Maintained a commendable energy density of 4.5 mWh cm⁻³, underscoring its strong potential for high-performance energy storage applications.

Biomass-derived carbon materials, such as those obtained from palm waste, represent an abundant and renewable resource for supercapacitor applications due to their high porosity and specific surface area14. However, translating these materials into practical devices requires overcoming several challenges, including the low intrinsic conductivity of palm-derived carbons, the absence of well-developed hierarchical pore structures, limited heteroatom doping efficiency, and poor electrochemical stability15. A notable advancement in this area is the development of a one-step microwave activation strategy to synthesize hierarchical porous carbon from palm waste16. This method, based on a modified Taguchi approach, streamlines and accelerates the production process by utilizing activated carbons with varying specific surface areas, thereby enabling the rapid conversion of palm waste into high-performance carbon materials17. This innovative approach offers a cost-effective and scalable solution for producing carbon electrodes for energy storage applications, helping to address one of the key bottlenecks in commercialization18.

As research in this field continues to advance, carbon-based supercapacitors are expected to play an increasingly important role in the transition toward a more sustainable and energy-efficient future. In this context, we have undertaken the preparation of activated carbon from palm waste fiber as a base material. The synthesized activated carbon was characterized using Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) to investigate its structural and surface morphology. Furthermore, electrochemical analyses were conducted to evaluate the charge storage capacity and overall performance of the activated carbon.

sec.title: Production of activated carbon from palm waste fibers
sec.p: Activated carbon fibers were prepared using palm fiber waste as the precursor, following the Taguchi method19. Approximately 30–50 g of pre-treated precursor were placed in an alumina horizontal tubular furnace, as illustrated in Fig. 1. The 100 mm diameter tube furnace, equipped with a 350 mm Heating zone, was controlled by a PID automatic system with 30 programmable segments via a Silicon Controlled Rectifier (SCR). The tube was evacuated using an oil-free DyTel mechanical pump to achieve a vacuum level of 1 mTorr. Carbon fibers (CF) were carbonized at two different temperatures − 500 °C and 800 °C - using a constant Heating rate of 10 °C/min for 1 h. After carbonization, the samples were cooled to room temperature under a nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting char, along with additional pre-treated samples, was activated by soaking in 50 mL of a 6.0 mol/L KOH solution at a 15% w/v concentration overnight to ensure thorough impregnation. The soaked samples were then dried in an oven at 105 °C and placed in the furnace under a nitrogen flow of 85 cm³/min at room temperature for 20 min20. Subsequently, the furnace temperature was increased at a rate of 2 °C/min to reach activation temperatures of 500 °C and 800 °C (denoted as ACK500 and ACK800, respectively), which were Maintained for 1 h. Finally, the activated carbon fibers were allowed to cool under an inert atmosphere, thoroughly washed with distilled water to remove residual chemicals, and dried in an oven overnight at 105 °C to obtain the final activated carbon fibers21.

caption.p: Activated carbon experimental system and produced material in the Thermal Management and Sustainable Research Laboratory: a) Vacuum furnace tube, b) Palm fibers, c) Activated carbon in fiber form, d) Activated carbon in powder form.

sec.p: 2.2 Preparation of carbon fibers.

To produce palm-based activated carbon (PAC) fibers in powder form, approximately 5 to 10 g of PAC were processed using a ball-milling apparatus. The amplitude of the Milling was kept constant, and the procedure was conducted at a frequency ranging from 2000 to 3000 vibrations per Minute for durations between 1 and 48 h under ambient atmospheric conditions. Following the milling process, the material was annealed to obtain high-quality PAC powder with improved structural and functional properties.

Palm waste fibers were initially collected and thoroughly washed with tap water, followed by several rinses with distilled water to remove surface impurities. The cleaned fibers were then soaked in n-hexane for 24 h to extract residual oils. After filtration, the fibers were rinsed multiple times with hot distilled water to eliminate any remaining n-hexane. Subsequently, the fibers were soaked in 30% sulfuric acid (denoted as –SW–) for 24 h to enhance surface activation. Finally, the samples were washed thoroughly with distilled water to remove residual acid and dried in an oven at 110 °C for 24 h22.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The pure carbon fibers (CF) and activated carbon fibers (ACFs) produced at 500 °C and 800 °C were characterized using Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM). FTIR analysis was conducted to identify the functional groups present in the ACFs, using a wavenumber range of 400 to 4000 cm⁻¹. Spectra were acquired with a Nicolet 750 spectrometer (Spectra Lab Scientific Inc., Canada). For sample preparation, activated carbon fibers were mixed with potassium bromide (KBr) in a 1:25 ratio and pressed into 10 mm pellets using a hydraulic press. The surface morphology of both pristine carbon fibers and ACFs was examined using SEM. Prior to imaging, the CF samples were coated with a thin layer of gold by sputtering. SEM imaging was performed using a Hitachi S-520 scanning electron microscope (Hitachi Ltd., USA). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis was conducted using a Micromeritics instrument (USA), such as the ASAP 2020, which is a high-precision analytical device for measuring specific surface area and porosity via nitrogen gas adsorption at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). For sample preparation, approximately 20 mg of finely powdered or fibrous carbon material was weighed into a clean glass or quartz sample cell. The samples were then degassed to remove moisture and volatile contaminants - typically under vacuum or inert gas flow (e.g., N₂ or He) at elevated temperatures (around 100 °C, depending on thermal stability) for 4 h. This ensures all pores are open and accessible to the adsorbate gas. After degassing, the sample was sealed and transferred to the BET instrument for analysis under controlled conditions to determine surface area and pore characteristics. Direct current (DC) conductivity measurements were performed using the Kelvin two-probe method across a temperature range of 25 to 200 °C. The measurements were carried out using a Keithley 2400 Source Measure Unit (SMU), manufactured in India.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Carbon fiber derived from waste Palm fibers represents a cost-effective and sustainable source of carbon-based Materials. Due to their initially low electrical conductivity, the carbon fibers were subjected to surface functionalization using a 15% w/v KOH solution23. The functional groups present in the carbon fibers were identified through Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, as illustrated in Fig. 2. The formation of carbon fibers was confirmed by prominent peaks in the FTIR spectra, including a peak at 1636 cm⁻¹ corresponding to the C = O stretching vibration, along with bands at 1501 cm⁻¹, 1332 cm⁻¹, and 3402 cm⁻¹ attributed to C–C bending vibrations24. After activation at 500 °C and 800 °C in the presence of KOH, the activated carbon fibers displayed notable peaks at 3432 cm⁻¹ and 2880 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the stretching vibrations of hydroxyl (O–H) and carbonyl (C = O) groups, respectively25–27, indicating successful surface functionalization, as shown in Fig. 1. Additional FTIR peaks include a C–C bending vibration at 1501 cm⁻¹, C–O stretching at 1326 cm⁻¹, in-plane C–H bending at 1242 cm⁻¹, and out-of-plane C–H bending at 608 cm⁻¹28,29.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of pristine carbon fiber and activated carbon fiber prepared at temperatures of 500 °C and 800 °C.

sec.p: Carbon fibers were prepared using a chemical oxidative method followed by carbonization at different temperatures to enhance their structural and electrochemical properties. Achieving the appropriate morphology is crucial for optimizing performance in specific applications. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) was employed to examine the surface morphology of both pristine carbon fibers (CF) and activated carbon fibers carbonized at 500 °C and 800 °C30. Figure 3 presents the SEM images of the carbon fibers and the activated carbon fibers prepared at 500 °C and 800 °C, respectively.

caption.p: SEM images of pristine carbon and activated carbon fibers prepared at temperatures of 500 °C and 800 °C.

sec.p: Figure 3(a) shows the carbon fiber derived from Palm fiber waste without any activation or thermal treatment. The surface exhibits large, agglomerated grains with an average size of approximately 0.87 μm, forming irregular spherical clusters32. The surface morphology of carbon fibers can be influenced by several factors, including mechanical stress, exposure to abrasive chemicals, and ultraviolet (UV) radiation. For example, repeated bending or impact may lead to delamination or microcracking on the fiber surface, resulting in increased surface roughness33.

In contrast, the carbon fiber shown in Fig. 3(b), which was calcined at 500 °C, exhibits a rod-shaped, fused agglomerated structure. This morphology May result from the coalescence of grain boundaries during thermal treatment, leading to an increase in grain size. Despite this, the average grain size is measured to be around 1.38 μm34. Achieving an optimized structure - characterized by high surface area and a well-defined pore architecture - is essential for improving charge storage capacity. Figure 3(c) illustrates the morphology of carbon fibers calcined at 800 °C, showing a diameter of approximately 0.24 μm at the joint nodes. This fine structure enhances the applicability of carbon fibers in energy storage devices and in environmental applications, such as the removal of pollutants from water and air. Moreover, the surface morphology of activated carbon fibers (ACFs) significantly affects their mechanical properties, contributing to their strength and durability35.

sec.title: Nitrogen physisorption
sec.p: The nitrogen (N₂) adsorption–desorption isotherms of carbon fiber and activated carbon fiber are shown in Fig. 4(a). As a characteristic feature of mesoporous carbon materials, the isotherm corresponds to a Type IV curve with a distinct hysteresis loop at higher relative pressures. The observed Type H1 hysteresis loop within the relative pressure range (P/P₀) of 0.4 to 0.8 is typically associated with cylindrical or spherical pores. In contrast, a Type H3 hysteresis loop, which appears at higher relative pressures, indicates the presence of slit-shaped pores with uneven geometries36. The activating agent, KOH (15% w/w), plays a critical role in chemically etching the carbon surface, promoting roughness and facilitating the formation of micropores. This is achieved primarily through its reaction with disordered carbon and the removal of volatile carbon atoms. The presence of both H1 and H3 hysteresis loops in the N₂ isotherms confirms that the activated carbon fiber (ACF) retains its mesoporous structure, even after activation and potential electrolyte exposure. During activation, metallic potassium (K) intercalates into the carbon lattice, expanding and disrupting the structure37. Additional mesopores and micropores are formed as the carbon matrix is further etched by CO₂ and H₂O released from KOH decomposition. The specific surface areas of the untreated carbon fiber and the KOH-activated carbon fiber (ACK800) are 297 m²/g and 2248 m²/g, respectively. This significant increase in accessible surface area is attributed to pore widening and the formation of high-density micropores38. Notably, activation at 800 °C with a high KOH-to-carbon ratio enables KOH to permeate and activate not only the outer surface but also the internal structure of the fiber wall, contributing to the development of a well-connected porous network.

caption.p: (a). Surface area analysis using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis: N2 adsorption - desorption isotherm of carbon fiber. (b). BJH pore size & volume analysis – Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) of carbon fiber and KOH-activated carbon fiber at 800 °C.

sec.p: The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was employed to determine the pore size distribution in activated carbon fibers, as shown in Fig. 4(b). The raw carbon fiber exhibits a highly compact, agglomerated, and non-porous structure. During the carbonization of the organic precursor, tightly packed carbon sheets are formed, effectively eliminating most of the initial porosity. As a result, the raw carbon fiber displays a low pore volume of less than 0.25 cm³/g and an average pore size below 5 nm. Most of the pores are ultramicropores that are poorly connected, rendering raw carbon fiber unsuitable for applications requiring high surface area or adsorption capacity39.

Significant structural changes occur when the carbon fiber is chemically activated with potassium hydroxide (KOH). At elevated temperatures (e.g., 800 °C), KOH reacts with carbon, producing gases such as CO₂ and H₂, and forming metallic potassium, which intercalates into the carbon matrix. These reactions etch the carbon surface, open previously closed pores, and break down parts of the dense carbon structure. As a result, new micropores and mesopores are formed, and existing pores are widened, significantly enhancing both surface area and porosity.

Following activation, the average pore size increases to approximately 134 nm, and the total pore volume reaches up to 0.981 cm³/g, depending on activation conditions. This transformation is driven by the chemical and physical interactions between KOH and carbon, which effectively “carve out” a porous network within the rigid carbon matrix40. The combined increase in pore size and volume leads to a substantial rise in specific surface area - from 297 m²/g in raw carbon fiber (CF) to 2248 m²/g in activated carbon fiber (ACF). These enhanced properties make KOH-activated carbon fibers highly effective in applications such as gas adsorption, energy storage (e.g., supercapacitors), and catalysis, where accessible surface area and internal porosity are critical.

The thermal conductivity of the produced activated carbon fibers (ACFs) and untreated carbon fibers was measured over the temperature range of 25 °C to 190 °C, using palm waste fiber as the precursor, as shown in Fig. 5. In recent decades, researchers have extensively investigated thermal conductivity to enhance the thermal performance of carbon-based materials through various approaches, including surface modification, doping, and controlled carbonization. The high thermal conductivity of the synthesized ACFs has promising implications for diverse applications, particularly in the energy sector. These materials can serve as electrode components in supercapacitors and batteries, potentially improving the performance, stability, and efficiency of energy storage devices41.

However, certain limitations and challenges persist regarding the thermal conductivity of synthesized ACFs. Parameters such as porosity, surface chemistry, and structural defects can significantly affect heat transport within the fiber matrix42. To Mitigate these issues and enhance thermal conductivity, innovative synthesis strategies and advanced characterization techniques are essential. In our study, the carbon fibers were treated with a 15% w/v KOH solution to improve their thermal transport properties43.

We observed that the thermal conductivity of the activated carbon fibers increases with temperature, likely due to the presence of intercalated K⁺ ions and the extended conjugated structure of the carbon matrix. These fibers exhibit semiconducting behavior, with three distinct stages of conductivity. At lower temperatures, conductivity increases gradually due to the stable movement of electron charge carriers through the extended network of the carbon structure44. As the temperature rises, a more pronounced, exponential increase in conductivity is observed, attributed to charge carrier hopping and the delocalized flow of π-electrons along the carbon backbone. Notably, the activated carbon fiber treated at 800 °C (ACK800) exhibited the highest thermal conductivity, reaching 0.64 S/cm45.

caption.p: Variation of DC conductivity as a function of carbonization temperature.

sec.title: Electrochemical measurement
sec.p: Activated carbon, carbon black, and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) were Mixed in a Mass ratio of 8:1:1. The Mixture was blended with ethanol, gently Heated, and stirred to form a uniform paste. This paste was then pressed to a thickness of approximately 150 μm and subsequently cut into circular electrodes with a diameter of 12 mm. The electrodes were vacuum-dried at 60 °C overnight. A symmetric button-type supercapacitor was then assembled using a polypropylene membrane as the separator46.

Heteroatoms play a critical role in enhancing the performance of supercapacitors when incorporated into carbon-based electrode materials. Doping carbon materials with heteroatoms such as nitrogen (N), sulfur (S), phosphorus (P), boron (B), and oxygen (O) can significantly improve properties essential for supercapacitor efficiency47. Heteroatom doping modifies the electronic structure of carbon materials, thereby enhancing their electrical conductivity. This improved conductivity facilitates faster electron transport during charge–discharge cycles, resulting in better rate capabilities and overall electrochemical performance48. Consequently, developing practical strategies for synthesizing hierarchical porous carbon with appropriately integrated heteroatom functional groups is highly desirable for the advancement of high-performance supercapacitors49.

Where E and P represent the energy density (Wh kg⁻¹) and power density (W kg⁻¹), respectively. Cₛ is the specific capacitance of a single electrode (F g⁻¹), V is the voltage range (V), and Δt is the discharge time (h).

Activated carbon is widely used in electrochemical applications due to its high surface area and porous structure. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) is a powerful technique for analyzing redox behavior and evaluating the electrochemical performance of materials such as activated carbon. In this study, the electrochemical properties of activated carbon fibers produced at two different carbonization temperatures − 500 °C and 800 °C - were examined using a two-electrode configuration in an electrolyte containing 15% w/v KOH (6.0 M). Figures 6(a) and 6(b) display the CV curves of CF, ACK500, and ACK800 recorded at a sweep rate of 50 mV/s51.

In Fig. 6(a), the CV curves of the activated carbon electrodes exhibit nearly rectangular shapes, characteristic of ideal capacitive behavior. Among the samples, ACK800 shows the strongest current response and the largest enclosed area, indicating a significantly higher capacitance compared to CF and ACK500. This behavior differs from that of materials exhibiting faradaic processes, which typically show distinct peaks or waves due to specific redox reactions52. Furthermore, Fig. 6(b) demonstrates that the rectangular shape of the CV curve for ACK800 remains consistent as the scan rate increases from 5 mV/s to 35 mV/s. This shape retention indicates excellent electrical double-layer capacitor (EDLC) behavior and high electrochemical reversibility during the charge–discharge process53.

caption.p: Variation of CV as a function of applied potential from 0 to 2.2 V.

sec.p: The galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves for the CF, ACK500, and ACK800 electrodes, measured at a current density of 1.0 A g⁻¹, are presented in Fig. 7(a). All curves exhibit a nearly triangular shape, indicative of high Coulombic efficiency and excellent electrochemical reversibility. Among the electrode materials, the GCD curves show minimal voltage drops, suggesting that CF and ACK500 possess low equivalent series resistance (ESR)54.

Figure 7(b) illustrates that the voltage drops for ACK500 and ACK800 increase progressively as the current density rises from 1.0 A g⁻¹ to 10 A g⁻¹. This behavior is attributed to the movement of electrolyte ions from the electrode surface into its interior during the charge–discharge process. At higher current densities, the pore structure and size of the electrode material play a critical role in ion transport. Smaller pore diameters can impede ion accessibility to the internal regions of the electrode, leading to larger voltage drops55.

Additionally, the GCD curves of ACK500 and ACK800 display longer discharge times at 1.0 A g⁻¹ compared to the other materials, indicating higher specific capacitance. Based on the previously described formulas (1) and (2), the specific capacitance values for ACK500 and ACK800 are calculated to be 207.5 F g⁻¹ and 223.4 F g⁻¹, respectively—both of which surpass the values reported for many commercial carbon materials. These results are also comparable to those of other biomass-derived carbon materials, as shown in Table 1. Another important aspect of evaluating activated carbon materials through cyclic voltammetry is their cycling stability. Activated carbon has consistently demonstrated excellent long-term stability across numerous cycles, making it a highly reliable material for electrochemical energy storage applications56.

caption.p: Variation of the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves of (a) untreated carbon fiber and activated carbon fiber at 500 and 800 °C as a function of time nad (b) shows the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) curves different current densities against time for ACK800.
Comparison of reported biomass carbon materials.

sec.p: The specific capacitance values for carbon fiber (CF) were determined by analyzing the discharge curves of the electrode materials. The specific capacitance of the ACK500 and ACK800 electrodes was calculated using formulas (1) and (2) described earlier, with the results presented in Figs. 8(a) and 8(b). Among the tested samples, ACK800 exhibits the highest specific capacitance and superior rate performance. Specifically, ACK800 delivers capacitance values of 223.4, 168.5, 138.5, 142.2, and 141.1 F g⁻¹ at current densities of 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 A g⁻¹, respectively. As the current density increases from 1.0 A g⁻¹ to 10 A g⁻¹, the Material retains 95.68% of its initial capacitance. At equivalent current densities, ACK500 and ACK800 exhibit comparable specific capacitance values; for example, ACK800’s capacitance decreases from 223.4 F g⁻¹ to 141.1 F g⁻¹, corresponding to a retention rate of 97.24%. In contrast, CF shows a more pronounced decline in capacitance with increasing current density. Among the three materials, ACK800 clearly demonstrates the best rate capability68,69.

The superior electrochemical performance of ACK800 can be attributed to its well-developed hierarchical pore structure, which provides a high density of active sites and an interconnected conductive network. This configuration facilitates efficient charge transport and reduces ion diffusion distances. The high surface area of activated carbon allows for enhanced ion adsorption, resulting in increased energy density. Moreover, its excellent electrical conductivity further improves energy storage capabilities70. The structural tunability of activated carbon enables the optimization of pore size and surface area for specific application requirements. The enhanced specific capacitance of ACK800 compared to CF is also linked to its higher oxygen content, which introduces additional pseudocapacitive behavior. Additionally, the abundant carbon content in ACK800 supports superior rate performance, whereas CF - characterized by more disordered carbon crystallites is more prone to degradation under high current densities71.

Energy density and power density are critical parameters for evaluating supercapacitor performance. These values for CF, ACK500, and ACK800 were calculated using formulas (3) and (4), and the results are depicted in the Ragone plot in Fig. 8(b). ACK800 achieves a Maximum energy density of 8.57 Wh kg⁻¹ and a corresponding power density of 104 W kg⁻¹, both of which surpass those of supercapacitors based on commercial activated carbon. These results highlight the versatility and efficiency of activated carbon materials and reinforce their suitability for advanced energy storage applications across various industries72.

caption.p: Specific capacitance of (a) CF, ACK500 and ACK800 at different current densities; and (b) the Ragone plot of CF, ACK500 and ACK800 against powder density.

sec.p: A study was conducted to evaluate the cycling stability of ACK800 electrodes at a current density of 1.0 A g⁻¹ in a 15% w/v KOH solution. As shown in Fig. 9, ACK800 retained 95.68% of its initial discharge capacity after 500 cycles, with no noticeable degradation in performance. Coulombic efficiency, calculated as the ratio of discharge capacity to charge capacity during each cycle, serves as a key indicator of the electrochemical reversibility and stability of supercapacitor materials73,74. The efficiency curves indicate that the ACK800 electrodes Maintain a Coulombic efficiency of approximately 97.2%, reflecting excellent reversibility and the absence of significant side reactions during the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) process. In summary, the ACK800 electrodes demonstrate outstanding charge-discharge efficiency and exceptional cycling stability, making them highly promising for long-term energy storage applications.

caption.p: Cycling stability and coulombic efficiency of ACK800.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Palm waste fiber was utilized as a precursor to prepare activated carbon fibers (ACFs), which were subsequently activated at two distinct temperatures—500 °C and 800 °C—using a 15% KOH solution. Structural analysis via Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy revealed the formation of carbon frameworks with K⁺ ions integrated into their structure. Surface morphology analysis using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) demonstrated that the carbon fiber activated at 800 °C exhibits a hierarchically porous structure. In contrast, the raw carbon fiber displays a compact, agglomerated, and non-porous morphology, resulting in a low pore volume (< 0.25 cm³/g) and an average pore size of less than 5 nm. For the activated carbon fiber, pore size increased to approximately 134 nm, and total pore volume reached up to 0.981 cm³/g. This structural transformation is driven by the chemical and physical interaction between KOH and the carbon matrix, which effectively “carves out” a network of pores within the dense structure. Electrical conductivity measurements indicated that ACK800 exhibits a high conductivity of 0.64 S/cm, attributed to the consistent flow of charge carriers across its extended and well-developed surface area.

The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve of ACK800 demonstrates a strong current response and encloses the largest area among the tested samples, indicating a higher capacitance relative to CF and ACK500. Notably, the rectangular shape of the CV curve remains largely unchanged as the scan rate increases from 5 mV/s to 35 mV/s, signifying excellent electrochemical reversibility and well-defined electrical double-layer capacitor (EDLC) behavior during the charge–discharge process. The specific capacitance of ACK800 was measured at 223.4, 168.5, 138.5, 142.2, and 141.1 F/g at current densities of 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 A/g, respectively. As the current density increased from 1.0 A/g to 10 A/g, ACK800 Maintained a capacitance retention of 95.68%, with no discernible degradation and 94.2% retention of its initial discharge capacity. Coulombic efficiency curves further confirmed that ACK800 achieves approximately 97.2% Coulombic efficiency, reflecting excellent reversibility and the absence of detrimental effects during galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) cycling.

Overall, the surface morphology, high conductivity, and excellent electrochemical performance of the activated carbon fibers highlight their potential as a sustainable and efficient solution for energy storage and battery applications.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: S.A.A. and N.B. and H.A.A. carried out experiments. A.O.M.A. contributed to data collection. N.B. and A.I. wrote the main manuscript. T.A.A. and A.S.A. prepared figures. All authors reviewed the manuscript.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: The authors extend their appreciation to the Deanship of Research and Graduate Studies at University of Tabuk for funding this work through Research no.0091-1444-S.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets used during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
